description: Humans relate to one another in couples, families, groups, organizations and communities.
Through the lens of social systems theory, ethics and a strengths perspective, social work
majors apply prerequisite and advanced theoretical research material from biology, sociology
and psychology to assess situations encountered by social workers. Diverse examples are drawn
from novels -- Joy Luck Club, The Color of Water, A Poison Stronger than Love -- and from
students' autobiographies. Prerequisites: Sociology 121 or 126, Psychology 241, and Biology
123 or 243; open to non-majors by permission of program director only. Offered Fall Semester.
fullname: Human Behavior in the Social Environment
